channel.title: Quests - Why are there no time put into those?
channel.description:
Quests are fun for a lot of people. I feel like NO ONE does quests on their RSPS's though. Whether it be RS quests or custom quests, why doesn't anyone take time into those?
Most F2P quests are really easy to do it and they aren't hard at all! Just time consuming. Finding the youtube video to copy the dialogue can be difficult sometimes. But besides that, its not hard at all!
If you think I'm right that it would greatly improve the RSPS community to add quests to our servers, what do you think it would take to get people to do so?
If you think I'm wrong, just tell me why. I'm curious to know why you don't think they'll be an improvement.

item.title: Quests - Why are there no time put into those?
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“Elrick, post:57, topic:526179”][quote author=wildskiller link=topic=644922.msg4347412#msg4347412 date=1376087988]
Quests aren’t hard to make, but if you want to make a fun custom quest, you need to take the TIME to do it. It takes me hours to do so
[/quote]
Most of you guys are like 16, and its Summer. I’m not sure if you’re insinuating that people don’t have the time, or are just too lazy and don’t take the time.[/quote]

I’d rather be out with my friends than sit inside programming all day

Read full topic

item.title: Quests - Why are there no time put into those?
item.dc:creator: @Teem_Rocket Teem_Rocket
item.description:
@Teem_Rocket wrote:

[quote=“Kidpaparoach, post:54, topic:526179”][quote author=Teem_Rocket link=topic=644922.msg4346205#msg4346205 date=1375914121]

Just saying for all the noobies thinking that adding quest is a good idea it isn’t. I’m not saying it’s a bad idea, it just saying depends on what type of server you want and most servers shouldn’t and don’t want them.

In my opinion in 99.99% of servers quests are unneeded and unwanted - nuff said.

I think that Quests which are a prerequisite to unlocking gear and such are a bad idea. However, I think that Quests in general are solid and aren’t time consuming if you create a storage system. I’m not a newbie at all, and I like the concept of Quests. It opens up a lot of extra content for players as well.
[/quote]
Re-read my post, read your reply and then re-read my post again. You’ll notice you completely misunderstood my post.[/quote]

I didn’t misread anything. I was giving my input. Thanks.

Read full topic

item.title: Quests - Why are there no time put into those?
item.dc:creator: @Int_Bauk Int Bauk
item.description:
@Int_Bauk wrote:

because the majority of people dislike quests. they only quested in RS to get the items they needed (barrows gloves for instance). however, it did outline a storyline for players and the overall concept of RS which some people liked. i highly doubt most servers these days have a concept and/or storyline, therefore, quests aren’t needed because their mainly revolved around bosses, minigames and pking - in which you can obtain the quest items from.

who wants to spend time doing a meaningless quest on a RuneScape Private Server?

just a thought for food.

Read full topic

item.source: Quests - Why are there no time put into those?

item.title: Quests - Why are there no time put into those?
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:42, topic:526179”]The thing about a quest API is that there’s a lot of stuff that needs to be covered in it. How would you implement giving Larry the money and killing the cat into that example, Vain?[/quote]easy. generally there are only x amount of actions that can be done in said server.

the api just needs to handle all stage actions such as , (item)

basically if a requirement is set as an item, in

<requirements> <skill id="strength" level="90"> <item id="995" amount="500000"> </requirements>you would just need to make some sort of method call in the xml stage, such as or some sort.

then in the api itself, just create a check for tag then pseudo: if (player.hasItem(PARSED.DATA.ITEM.ATTRIBUTE, PARSED.DATA.AMOUNT.ATTRIBUTE)) {
deleteItem();
}[/code]etc. etc.

all you have to do is think of all possible outcomes of a quest. (item gets deleted whilst talking to npc//do an emote perhaps//wield specific items//kill an npc//talk to an npc//click an item(such as spade)//click an object//pick up an item//etc)

once you obtain a list of all outcomes, just create method calls (tags/attributes) in the xml, and then parse the data and add checks for it server sided.

it will be just like writing a quest now, except when you’re checking something (if a player has item) you wont define the item, but rather a tag.

Read full topic

item.title: Quests - Why are there no time put into those?
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

would be much easier to write one yourself.

any type of data parsing. i’d probably choose xml or json for it’s simplicity

parse a full directory /quests/ load all files of the correct format

sample:

[code=XML]


























MAN hey man. thanks for taking time to talk can u go give my friend larry 500k yes no way man 
<stage id="1">
  <npc>LARRY</npc>
  <message>
    <line>oh great thanks for 500k</line>
    <line>it means a lot to me<line>
    <line>will you please tell man i said thanks</line>
  </message>
  <options>
    <one>no i hate him</one>
    <two>yeah ill talk to him<two>
    <three>why is this option here<three>
  </options>
  <action option="one">
    <set variable="thisQuestVar" value="10"> <!-- used for saving to file -->
    <set stage="2">
  </action>
  <action option="two">
    <set variable="thisQuestVar" value="20"> <!-- used for saving to file -->
    <set stage="1">
  </action>
  <action option="three">
    <!-- no action set cause option has no purpose -->
  </action>
</stage>

<stage id="2">
  <npc>MAN</npc>
  <message>
    <line>oh good. i heard larry got the money</line>
    <line>if you can kill this cat ill pay you<line>
    <line>with a cannon or some rune armor</line>
    <line>but i doubt you are strong enough</line>
  </message>
  <options>
    <one>cats are easy to kill</one>
    <two>im an animal lover<two>
    <three>you cant kill a cat?<three>
    <four>id rather kill you<four>
  </options>
  <action option="one">
    <set variable="thisQuestVar" value="30"> <!-- used for saving to file -->
    <set stage="3">
  </action>
  <action option="two">
    <!-- no action set cause option has no purpose -->
  </action>
  <action option="three">
    <!-- no action set cause option has no purpose -->
  </action>
  <action option="four">
    <!-- no action set cause option has no purpose -->
  </action>
</stage>

<stage id="3">
  <npc>MAN</npc>
  <message>
    <line>dont talk to me!</line>
    <line>kill that beast!!<line>
  </message>
</stage>

<stage id="4">
  <npc>MAN</npc>
  <message>
    <line>congrats u killed it!</line>
    <line>now dance on his grave for the luls<line>
  </message>
</stage>

<stage id="5">
  <npc>MAN</npc>
  <message>
    <line>thanks for helping kill the cat</line>
    <line>i hope you enjoy your reward<line>
  </message>
</stage>
CAT_NPC DANCE_EMOTE [/code]if you cannot read this and get a general idea on how to parse it or how to make your own with this amount of scalability then you dont need to attempt to do so. now this just gives you ideas on how to go about doing it. but it can be further improved by a lot

Read full topic

item.title: Quests - Why are there no time put into those?
item.dc:creator: @Teem_Rocket Teem_Rocket
item.description:
@Teem_Rocket wrote:

"Hans the Corrupt". This Quest is an example of how multiple approaches will be able to be utilized to solve the Quest. In this Quest, Sir Percival (Knight of the Square Table) requests an audience with the Player. The Player learns after having spoke with Sir Percival, that one of Cynosure's most beloved public figures - Hans - may be using Forbidden Magic (Administrators will have this Spell Book at their disposal eventually), to create Coins from Gold via Dark Alchemy. The Player may speak with Hans, but Hans will not reveal anything without a Disposition of 100. With a Disposition of 100, Hans will admit to it and the Quest will finish up quickly. Without it, however, the Player must either: 1. Pickpocket the information from Hans (20 Theiving Required), 2. Search Hans' Castle for the information, or 3. Defeat Hans in Combat (Hans will transform into a Monster via Forbidden Magic). In the end, however, the outcome will be the same. Hans and yourself are teleported to the Knights of the Square Table for a confrontation. After finding Hans guilty of the use of Forbidden Magic for personal gain, he is sentenced to be banished (inside an Instanced Dungeon). Hans makes many later appearances in-game as an enemy of the Knights of the Square Table.

Pre-requisites:

  • Combat Level of 20.

Rewards:

  • 1,000,000 Coins (the Coins Hans made from his Dark Alchemy)
  • Iron Armor Set (Item Quality Mundane)
  • Emerald Ring (Item Quality Common)
  • Black 2-Handed Sword (Item Quality Uncommon)
"The Square Party". This Quest is do-able from Combat Level 1, and has no pre-requisites to start or complete. This Quest also serves as an example of the N.P.C. V.S. N.P.C. Combat System. At the beginning of the game, once a Player has been in-game for a certain period of time, a N.P.C. walks up to the Player with an Invitation from the Knights of the Square Table. The Invitation reads that the Knights are throwing a party, and would like for the Player to attend. Upon visiting their Castle, a Cutscene begins, and shows a Vampire escaping from their Castle Dungeon. The Player procceeds into the Castle, where another Cutscene plays depicting how the Knights of the Square Table party (by standing at their Square Table with Drinks spawned in front of them onto the table and telling jokes via N.P.C. Text Updates). The Vampire bursts into the room, and the Knights attempt to Slay the Vampire, but cannot kill it without Garlic. The Player is to search the Castle for some Garlic (found in the Castle Kitchen). Once the Player finds the Garlic, they must use it on the Vampire when it is close enough to death (the Knights fight the Vampire).

Rewards:

  • 100,000 Coins

  • Ability to access a Minigame where the Player can prepare meals for the Knights of the Square Table. Be careful not to burn the food though!

“Quests - Why are is no time or effort put into these?”

“effort”

/thread

Read full topic
